The attention of the - Cabinet was invited, asa matter of urgency, to President Coolidge'smemorandum suggesting an immediate Conferenceof Naval Powers at Geneva for the further reduction and limitation of naval armaments (See washington telegram No. 92 of February 11th; also paper cp.-59 (27), to be circulated).The Prime Minister informed the Cabinet thathe had had a conversation on the previous eveningwith the Secretary of State for E^reign Affairs,the Lord President of the Council, the Chancellorof the Exchequer, the Secretary of State forDominion Affairs, the First Lord of the admiralty and the Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, asthe result of which a draft reply to PresidentCoolidge had been drawn up for consideration bythe Cabinet.The draft telegram referred to was then read to the Cabinet.After some discussion, in the coarse of which some verbal amendments to the draft telegram were proposed, the Cabinet agreed (a) That the exact wording of the draft telegram, which should contain anacceptance of President Coolidge1sproposal, subject to certain obser-vations , should be left to theSecretary of State for ForeignAffaira:(b) That, as a first step, the Secretaryof State for Dominion Affairs should send a copy of the telegram, approved as in (a), to the Dominions, andshould invite their' concurrence inits terms:(c) That, after the approval of theDominions had been obtained, theSecretary of State for ForeignAffairs should have authority tomake a communication to the Ambassador of the United States of Americain the terms of the draft telegram,and to notify the Governments of france , Italy and Japan of thenature of the reply.(NOTE: A copy of the draft telegramas sent to the Dominions isattached in the Appendix.)-2- 2. Referring to the reports in the Press thatthe agreements in regard to the future of theBritish Concessions at Hankow and Kiukiang had notbeen signed owing to some interpretation placed on sir Austen chamberlain's speech in the House ofCommons by Eugene Chen, the Secretary of State forForeign Affairs informed the Cabinet that he had as yet received no details from Mr 0*Mailey. at hankow. There appeared to have been a delay intelegraphic communications over the land lines inChina, and it was only that morning that a longtelegram had been received, which was now being de-ciphered but was not likely to be available in timefor communication to the Cabinet that morning.In the'circumstances Sir Austen Chamberlaindid not wish to raise any question regarding theposition in China. 3- The Cabinet had before them the following documents relating to British Policy towardsRussia:-A Draft Note to the Soviet Government,circulated by the Secretary of Statefor Foreign Affairs , prepared with aview to acquainting the Cabinet withthe published material available fora protest if such were desired(Paper CP.-17 (27)):A Note by the Secretary of State forIndia, suggesting an alteration inthe conclusion of the above (paper cp.-24 (27)):A Memorandum by the Minister of Labourgenerally in favour of the despatch and publication of the Note, subjeot tocertain observations' (Paper C P.-43(27)):A Memorandum by the Secretary of Statefor Foreign Affairs on the effect onforeign relations and on the internal situation in this country of a breachwith Soviet Russia (Paper CP.-25 (27)):A Memorandum by the Secretary of Statefor Dominion Affairs, prepared in 1924but re-circulated, setting forth theimportance of explaining to the Dominionsany change of policy contemplated byHis Majesty's Government before adecision is taken (Paper CP.-511 (24)):A Memorandum by the President of theBoard of Trade, explaining the effect which a breach with Soviet russia would exercise on trade relations(Paper CP.-27 (27)):An Account of a Conversation betweenthe Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs and M. Tradeand Industries) Bill" the object of which was to prohibit any person or association from inviting,aocepting or using funds from foreign sources forthe furtherance or malntenanoe of Industrial disputes in Great Britain .After a short discussion, the Cabinet agreed (a) That the Government could not give their support to a measure whichwould make it illegal for a TradesUnion engaged in an industrial dispute to receive contributions from abroad:(b) That the Home Secretary should inter-vene early in the Debate in order toexplain the objections to the-Bill:(c) That the Government Whips should notbe put on to oppose the Bill. APPENDIX.PROPOSED ANSWER. TO INVITATION FROM PRESIDENT OFTHpNITED"'STATES Off AMERICA TO"A CONFERENCE ON-KAVAL DISARMAMENT,His Majesty1^ Government received with cordial sympathythe invitation of the Government of the United States ofAmerica, to take part in a Conference at Geneva on the furtherlimitation of Naval Armaments.The views of His Majesty'e Government upon the specialgeographical position of the British Empire, the length of inter-imperial communications, and the necessity for the protectionof its food supplies are well-known, and together v/ith thespecial conditions and requirements of the other oountriesinvited to the Conference must he taken into account.His MsjestyTs Government are nevertheless prepared toconsider to what extent the principles adopted at Washingtonoan be carried further, either as regards the ratio in differentclasses of ships between the various Powers, or in other important ways. They therefore accept the invitation of theGovernment of the United States of America and will do their best to further the success of the Conference.They would, however, observe that the relationship of such a Conference to the proceedings of the PreparatoryCommission at Geneva would require careful adjustment.
